title.text: Temporal Expressions Extraction in SMS messages

abstractContent.text: This paper presents a tool for extracting and normalizing temporal expressions in SMS messages in order to automatically fill in an electronic calendar.

entities.text: extracting and normalizing temporal expressions in SMS messages

abstractContent.text: The extraction process is based on a library of finite-state transducers that identify temporal structures and annotate the components needed for the time normalization task.
An initial evaluation puts recall at 0.659 and precision at 0.795.

introductionContent.text: In this study, the extraction of temporal information in SMS messages is regarded as a precondition to the development of an application for the construction of a calendar.
This application includes the automatic analysis of meetings and the pre-filling of calendar events.
We consider the language of temporal expression in SMS messages as a sublanguage which forms a finite subset of the whole language at the syntactic and lexical levels.
Most of the recent studies () do not process SMS messages directly.
They use a heavy preprocessing step in order to standardize the SMS script.
We do not deny the relevance of the transliteration process for complex applications such as SMS messages vocalisation.

However, within the framework of our project, we show that, for the extraction of temporal expressions, a normalization phase is not needed, as we tend to simply identify the boundaries of precise and particular surface structures.
Before exploring the extraction task (Section 3), we briefly introduce the corpus used (Section 2).
The results of the evaluation we performed are outlined in Section 4, while Section 5 shows the prospects that emerge from this preliminary work.

datasetContent.text: We performed an evaluation for the task of temporal expression extraction.
We built an evaluation corpus and manually annotated the temporal expressions.
Results in terms of precison and recall are provided in Section 4.2.
The evaluation corpus is composed of 442 SMS messages containing temporal expressions, following the "calendar criterion".
Some SMS messages contain more than one temporal expression so the total number of temporal expressions is 666.
